div.p: A true and perfect description, of the last voyage or Nauigation, attempted by Capitaine Iohn Rybaut, deputie and generall for the French men, into Terra Florida, this yeare past. 1565. Truely sette forth by those that returned from thence, wherein are contayned things as lamētable to heare as they haue bene cruelly executed.
JMPRINTED at London by Henry Denham, for Thomas Hacket, and are to be solde at his Shop in Lumbart streate.

div.head: The Authour to his friend.
div.p:
REmembring the promes that I made vnto you when we did embarque or take shipping in this Hauen, for to accōplishe the viage of Florida, that, at my returne, if that the Lord God did permit me to returne, I would bring you newes from thence. And althoughe that since my returne, I haue often tymes deuised with you: yet notwithstanding, I thought good to doe a thing more agreable vnto you, to set forth in writing so much as I coulde well remember, and that for two reasons. One is, for that I knowe that you loue to heare published the greate wonders of God, which hath bene founde greate in thys discourse, when that shall be sene, the great daungers that he hath deliuered vs oute off, and hath of his mercy graunted vs to sée our owne natiue Countrey. The other
is, for that you shall gladlye heare tryed, the inconstancie and variable estate of humaine kinde, wherein his hye looke being abated, he learneth to call to God, as it appertayneth to magnifie hys highnesse, to walke vprightly in his obedience and seruice. You shall vnderstand (friend) to what end I speake this. The erperiēce sheweth, that it is a daungerous thing, when that not contented with our vocation, we are drawen backe from our desires, we do that that God defendeth, yea, yt which is nothing necessary. For what nedeth the handy crafts man to leaue his shop, the housholder his deare wyfe, his swéete children, his countrey, his owne & proper goods, for to go seke false & straūge thinges, seking to take shadowes, being guided by blinde guides. But euery one will touch felicity, the which can not be without the meanes of externe goods, yea euē so as is desputed in the schole of that great Philosopher Aristotle. I confesse it on condition, if you will graunte that that is verye little, wherewith nature is contented, and that reason demaundeth,
but the couetousnesse is greate & gapeth continually. Nowe we poore men at the least, ought to thinke on that which Homer sayth.

q.l: That not onely he that possesseth much is happy,
But he that the giftes of God can vse wysely,
He whom pouertie holdeth let him paciently beare,
He that seareth death is neuer the neare.
He that is cōtēt & prayseth fortunes state,
Let him not shrinke at all, though she hir wings do beate
He that seketh not to clime vp fortunes wheele,
But is content with his estate, muche good thereby shall feele.

div.p:
O how often is it come to my remembrance, during this perilious voyage, of that that I haue learned of Plinie, of one Gyges, that was the rychest of his tyme, how that he, being before the Oracle of Apollo, for to enquire of ye most happiest of men. The miscrable proud man vnderstood otherwise than the Oracle gaue answere, yt it was a poore olde man named Aglaus, which remayned in a corner of Arcadia, labouring and tilling a verye little ground which he had, and notwithstanding, it rendred ynough to sustaine
his lyfe and his family, and being cōtent with this kinde of lyfe, couetousnesse and desire of gaine coulde not once moue him to go out of his little Village: so that he hauing this benefite, was an occasion to auoyde many euilles, and to receyue the lesse sorrowe and bitternesse during his life, louing better his presente estate, than to desire otherwise, and more estéeming his condition than the estate of Kynges. As for mée I am nowe bent to this opinion, that you ought well to note, that the harme that maye chaunce in a mans house during his absence, among his wyfe and family, doth surpasse ye pleasure of triumph, which victory doth promisse. For what profited it to ye king of kings (for so Homer calleth him) to haue in ten yeares conquered & gottē the moste richest Region of his time, when that at his retourne, he founde his house chaunged and altered, the hearte of his wife rauished by the conceptions of adoultery (beholde the fruite of his voyage) he loseth his lyfe, his sonne banished, and retourning from his banishment, killeth
his mother, and the wicked fornicatour that kepte hir, it had bene better for him then, that went to vnpeople Troy, and to take by force Yllion, to haue taried at home with his wife Clytemnestra, thā to haue let a wicked man in his absence occupie his roume, and entise his wife to euill. Likewise of Helena, which bicause of hir husbands absēce, was rauished by ye amorous Paris: of Penelope which was required of so hote burning louers, whilest that the prudente and wise warriour Vlysses, trauayleth the seas to finde out his country. It is therefore our partes, that haue bent our cares to Iesus Christ Lord of our soules, & who alone ought to raigne in our consciences, to obey to his commaundementes, the which is, that a man should cleaue to his wife, and be to hir as glewe, for so haue I vnderstoode of our Doctours, that the worde doth sound Cula in the Hebrewe tongue. Morcouer, God cōmaundeth that the husband shuld render to his wife vnfayned loue & good will, but what is the remedie when that they are seperated. I knowe that instlye,
we haue felt ye rygor of Gods iudgemēts: yea for many causes, and principally, for leauing our families, the which we ought to care for most of all, next to God. Let them go to Florida who list, for my parte I would not wishe, that that man, that is a houshoulder, should so leaue his occupation, for to séeke his aduēture in a straūge countrey, & for a greater profite of gaine: what faire promysse so euer is made of his enterprise. Also, we haue borne the wrath and anger of God, as ye may sée in this discourse of Florida, which I do present vnto you, desiring you to receyue it as a token or pledge of my good will and loue, the whiche this fiftene yeares hath helde our heartes, straightly lyncked and ioyned together by Iesus Christ our Lorde, to whom alone appertayneth the rule, power & glory, for euer and euer. Amen.

div.head: ¶ Of Terra Florida:
or a memoriall Hystorie of that which hath happened in the last voiage by Capitaine Iohn Rybaut, enterprysed by the Kinges commaundement, at an Iland of the Indies which commonly is called Florida.

div.p:
THe king with manye Princes and Lords of his counsel, before that ye tumults and troubles of the Ciuill warre did ryse in his Realme, was minded to sende a competent number of men, with many shyppes, into one of the Countreys of India, named Florida, newlye discouered and knowē by the French men. Wherefore after that this Cyuill tumult was appeased and published, by his Maiesties authoritie, the pretended
purpose cōtinued. And for the executing of this enterprise, Iohn Ribaut a man of heart and of counsell, and well séene in nauigation, was sence for to the Court, and there receiued the kings commission to appoint seuen shippes, that might carrye thyther, men, vittayles, and munitions of warre, honouring him with the tytle of Lieutenant, or generall of all the men of warre, the which he had cōmission and commaundement to presse and take vp, expedient for such an enterprise. And to him it was expressiuely defended, to attempt to lande in any other Countrey or Ilande there, specially in any that is vnder the dominion of the king of Spaine, but yt in sayling the great Occean Sea, he should kéepe his full course to Florida. The newes of this voyage was soddenly spredde all abroade, and many were perswaded to submit them selues to the commaundement of this Capitaine, and vnder the kings auctoritie, being led with diuers affections: for some were pricked forward wt an honest desire for to knowe and sée the Coūtrey, hoping that the sayd
nauigatiō would profite them afterward. Others being desirous both with hearte and to minde, make warre, came thither also, louing rather to abide the rage of the waters, than to remaine in their wōted estate and condicion, the which occasiō might aswell prouoke one as another. The rumor that was spredde here, was: Florida promised sufficiencie and contentation, of al that man might desire in the worlde. For as much as that countrey receyued a singuler fauour from Heauen, for that there is neither Frost nor Snow of the coldenesse of Septentrion, nor yet the burning heate of the South. The fieldes without labouring and tilling, bring forth inough, wherewith to sustaine the lyfe of men that dwell or shall dwel or inhabit there. It séemeth for to make a coūtrey the moste fruitefullest, and rychest that is in the compasse of the worlde, if that there were men that woulde employ their industrie or diligence, in trimming of the ground to mans vse, the which extendeth from Aquilon to Septentrion, almost in the like longitude, as Europia,
and his latitude is .xxiii. degrées. Sometimes whē ye the beames of the sunne are spredde from the highest degrée, it receyueth great heate, the which notwithstanding, is tēpered not onely with the freshnesse of the night, or with the Dewe that falleth from heauen, but also with moste gracious raine falling aboundantlye, so that the ground is very fruitefull, yea, in such sort, that the grasse groweth of a wōderfull highnesse. It is also rich of golde, and with all sorts of wylde & tame beasts, which haue the fieldes fayre and large. Notwithstāding also, the Hilles are of a reasonable highnesse, the Flouds and Riuers very pleasant, dyuers kinde of trées rendring swéete smelling sauour. All this being considered, it coulde no otherwise be, but that man there shoulde haue great pleasure, and singuler delectation. Many therfore being ouercome with these faire promises, others with a couetous desire, thinking to be made ryche by this voyage, bicause of the gold, came by heapes to this towne, where ye mnster should be, for to choose those, which at the iudgement
of the Kinges Lieutenant, shoulde séeme most fitte for the beforenamed enterprise: but it was not so soone put to effect as some did desire, & specially those that had receiued the souldiers into their Innes and houses, for they were wery to haue men that made suche chéere, wythout paying the shotte, though that they promised them with assurance that shortlye they shoulde be contented and payed. And they were foure Monthes and more in thys Towne or euer they set forward. But in the ende, they were bounde by a certain othe, to behaue them selues faithfully in the kings seruice, receyuing wages for six Monthes, which at the last, was not to the Generals contentation. For about the Moneth of May. 1565. that againe the muster of men shoulde be for to take shipping, some of them that had receyued wages, being troubled in conscience, of so long a voyage, being also amazed to beholde the rage of ye Sea, chaūged their purpose, and withdrewe themselues secretly, without passing any further. Nowe for to make shorte, and least
they should dayly diminish, they were againe instantly called and, they were cōmaunded that at that verye houre, they shoulde take shipping, which was the tenth day of May, & we remayned in the Rode, till the .xxij. day of the before sayde Moneth, tarying for certaine beastes and corne. The number of men for this voyage were thrée hundreth, besides handycraftes men & their families. And whylest that we stayed for the commaundement and commoditie of our Lieutenant, and hauing the wind fauourable, the Tuesday being the .xxij. day of May, there did ryse a great tempest, the windes blowing vs from one parte to another, in suche sorte that the waues meting, with such a vyolent force, gaue such feare to our Mariners, that they could find no other proper remedy, but to cut the Cables, leaue the Ankers, and to giue vs ouer to the pleasure of the winde. The moste violentest winde that was, was a Northerly winde, the which draue vs so swiftly, that sodenly we were at New Hauen, and there we remayned thrée dayes, loking for newes
from Déepe by a Bringandine, that we sent straightly thither, and then we prepared oure selues, to departe from this Rode, the .xxvj. of the beforesaide Month, & as we thought to kepe our right course, incontinently a contrary winde tooke vs, and caused vs to retire to the Ile of Wiskam, one of the Countreys of England, where the English men were desirous to know of our enterprise, & after yt they had knowledge therof: they offred to doe vs pleasure. The daye that we arriued thither, was the .xxviij. of May, and there we did ride at an Ancker till ye .xiiij. of Iune, on the which day, we had the winde at the Northeast as faire as we did wish, so that we hoyssed vp our sayles, and sayled the right course to Florida, the which we did long to sée, and we remayned sayling the greate Occean Sea, two whole Monthes, before that we could haue sight of Terra Florida, sauing of an Iland, named by ye Pesants Vocaionques, some of our mē would haue named this Ilād Katherine by ye name of ye Quene, mother to the King: & they sayd, that it is .xxvij. degrées,
of latitude. We sawe also a shippe two hundreth Leagues beyond, towards the Sea, but we came not nere it, by thre or foure Leagues. When that we were aryued into Terra Florida, we perceyued the flers that the Indians made vs, which was the .xiiij. day of August. We sente a Erigandine to discouer a little Ryuer, and at the mouth of the Riuer, there were certain wilde mē, which did trucke siluer for our marchādise that we had brought, and they saide that they had that siluer, of a shippe that had bene cast away, cōming from Entailes. We found there a certain Spaniarde, escaped from a shipwracke twentie yeares agoe, whome we tooke vp into our Brigandine, and we did inquire of him, if he coulde tell any newes of the Frenche men, that kepte a holde in that Coūtrey: and he answered that he knew nothing, sauing yt he vnderstoode of those wilde men, that they were encamped fifty Leagues more Northwarde than where as they were aryued, so we set vp sayle and coasted al along ye coast, which semed to be the sandy lande, planted with little
trées all along, and the floudes that come from the Southwest are there very smal, and in ye mid way we discouered a Ryuer, that our men before tyme had named the Ryuer of May, whereas also the floudes are not very greate that come from the North northeast. And bycause of the shallownesse of the waters, we might sée the Anker holds yt before had bene there, and we founde within thrée or foure Leagues of lande, six or seuen fadome water, or there about. I remēber also, yt betwene the Ryuer of May & another named Aye, we founde another on the Northe syde, about two Leagues distant from the Ryuer of May, and there we cast Anker being benighted, hauing cyght or nine fadome water, finding the bottom in some places sandy, somtymes grauely, & much Oxias. We sounded also ye Ryuer of Dolphins, and there we found at the bar two fadome, but at a full Sea there is sound two fadome and thrée quarters. And after that we had long coasted the coast to find a landing place, the .xxvij. day of August, we cast oure Ankers in the Rode, of the
Ryuer of May, at seauen fadome water, being frō the lande about two Leagues. On Wednesday being the .xxix. of ye sayde Moneth, we entered into thrée Barges, & rowed vp the sayde Ryuer, straight to the holde where oure men kepte, the whiche they before time had made, for their place of assurance and rest, a place very cōmodious, as well for the Ryuer that it hath on the one side, & a wood on other ye side, which is distant not passing a quarter of a myle from the place, and a fayre fields betwene the wood and the Holde, and another side verye pleasaunt couered with grasse and hearbes, very long, and of diuers kinds: and there is no way into the Wood, sauing a little way made by oure men, about a mans pace, the which they had made in going to the fountaine that was in the sayde wood. When that we were aryued nere to the sayde place, our Lieutenant caused the vittayles to be discharged, & carryed to the Holde, with other munitions to recreate ye place, and also commaunded, that we handycraftes men with our wiues and children, should
go thither, and caused vs to be condutted thyther by a Gentleman of the house of Vlly, of Beauchaire, and others, to whome also he gaue the charge of his most precious cariage. Those that taryed for vs at the Fort, were greatly reioysed at our comming, for they were perplexed and troubled to be so long tyme without hearing any newes out of France, and that more augmented there dolour, they were without vittayles, vnlesse that they would accustome them selues to liue according to the order of the Countrey Inhabitantes, of whom also they could get nothing, but by violence and force, as we shall declare more plainelye hereafter. Nowe when that we were remayning there, I cōsidered the forme of the dwellers of the lande, which séemed to me good and gentle, for the men are straight and well proporcioned, somewhat of a ruddy colour. I vnderstoode that in euery village they haue a king, and for their clothing they haue Lether marked after a strange fashion, they haue no apparell neyther men nor women, but the women are girded
with a little valle or apron of the skin of some beast, for to couer the parte of nature that is most shamefast. Thei are neither flat nosed nor great lipped, but their face is rounde and full, their eyes cleare and feareful, their haire is very long, and they trusse it very properly round aboute their heades. And this trussing of their haire serueth them in stede of a Quiuer, to carry their arrowes when they goe to warre: it is maruellous to sée how sodēlye they haue them ready in their handes to shoote very farre and as streight as is possible. As touching their maners, they are dissolute, they instructe not their children, neyther yet correcte them, they wyll take without conscience, and al that they can catche secretlye, they counte it their owne. Euery one hath his owne wyfe, and they kepe maryage, yea, with all Rygor. They warre against the Countryes adiacent, which are of diuers languages. Their weapons are bowes and arrowes. Their houses are rounde almoste like a Doue house, founded and established with great trées, couered ouer with leaues of a
Palme trée. They feare not the windes and tempestes. They are often grieued with little flyes, which in their language they cal Maring • ns, and it behoueth them ordinarily to make fiers in their houses, specially vnder their beddes, to be delyuered of this vermine. They say that they sting cruelly, and that part that is touched with their stinging, looketh lyke the fleshe of a lazar. They estéeme nothing so rich and so faire as the feathers of Birds, being of dyuers colours. They estéeme muche little counters, that they make of the bones of certain fishes, & other grene stones and redde. Their foode is rootes, fruite, herbes, and fishes of diuers kinds, and their fish is very fatre that they hang to drye, the which they call in their language Boquarie, they take out the fat the which they vse in stéede of butter & saulse. They haue no corne, but they haue aboūdance of a certaine séede which groweth ye heigth of seuē foote, his stalke is great like a Cane, and the graine great like a pease, the eare is a foote long, the colour is of the colour of wax vnwrought: the meane
to vse it, is firste to bruse it and stampe it to meale, then afterwarde they vndoe it by mingling and make therwith their Mygan, which is like to Rice that is kept in this countrey. It must be eaten assone as it is made, bycause it will quicklye chaunge, for it is not to be kepte. They haue many bastarde Ʋynes growing about trées, as we sée in some Countreys of this Realme, but they haue not the vse to presse out the Wine. Their drinke they call Cassinet, is made with hearbes mingled together, and séemeth of the colour of Ale of our countrey, I haue tafted thereof, and it hath not bene straunge to me. As touching the countrey it, séemeth to me hilly. There are many Forrestes which maye be the occasion of so manye wilde beastes, ye which they say will hurt those that take not good heede. I wil leaue to speake many things of wilde beastes, ye which only I haue heard speake of, but it is inough for me to wryte that which I haue séene, and that séemeth to me worthy of memorie for the posteritie. And singulerly of Cocodrils, the which often
tymes are séene come forth of the sande to go séeke their pray, we haue sene many, specially one deade, and we haue eaten thereof, the which eateth tender, & white as veale, and almost of the same taste. He was killed with the shotte of a Gunne, stroken betwéene two skales, otherwyse they are strong inoughe for any strokes: his mouth very great, & his téeth straight like the téeth of a combe, his body was .xij. or .xiij. foote long, the legges very short to the proportion of the bodye, his nayles straunge and cruell, his tayle strong and long, wherin consisteth his life and principall defence. Also in the mouth I find no apperance of tongue, for he had the vpper parte vnder, a thing monsterous, whiche in beholding thereof is inoughe to giue feare to men. Also I did sée a serpent dead by the wood which had bene killed by one of our men, of which the wilde men cut of the heade, and did carry it away with greate care and diligence: I coulde not know the reason wherfore they did so. He had wings by the whiche he might sometymes flye vp from the ground. Some of
our men thought that the wilde men did it for some superstition, and as farre as I could sée, they are not without some opinion of diuinitie, like as I do coniecture by certaine circumstances, that easelye they might be brought to good ciuilitye and honestie, and also to holinesse & sound Religion, if that God of his mercy would vouchsafe it: for so soone as the Bell had rong for to goe to prayers of our Holde, they would be there, and stretch vp their handes to heauen as we did, yea, with reuerence and attentiue eare. In ye meane time, our gouernor was by for to acquite faithfullye his charge, and gaue order that the holde might be so ramperde and furnished, yt it might serue for a defence, least by aduēture ye barbarous mē might sodenly make an insurrectiō, & ouerrunne vs. Monday the third day of September, did ariue nere to our shippes fiue sayle of Spanishe ships, the Admiral being of the burthē of .iiij. hūdreth Tunnes, the Barke a hūdreth & fiftie Tunnes, being followed with thrée patences, the which came & cast Anker hard by our shippes about nine of
of the clocke towarde night, in the night they and our shippes spake together, and when that our men had asked them why they came to séeke them, they aunswered that they were enimies, and that the war was sufficiētly declared, so then our men beholding the strength of the Spaniards to their enuy and naughtye will, wayed their Ankers, and set vppe sayle, and the Spaniardes chased after them, but they coulde not get them by sayling, & therefore they retired into the Ryuer of Dolphins, and there they were minded to descende. And after that they had conspired our ruine with the wilde men, as ye issue of their enterprise in the ende sheweth, from this Ryuer they sente of their men by companies as many as they thought néedefull for to execute their enterprise. And since we vnderstoode of the wylde men, that they were in armour sixe hundréth men. Not long after, thrée of oure shippes being come againe to the Rode, (for the Trinitie our Admiral was borne downe the Riuer hauing no Anker holde) the Capitaine Iohn Rybaut was mynded
with these thrée shippes to pursue the Spaniards: and after that he had counsailed with his men vpon this enterprise, shewing vnto them that it was necessary to shewe their force vpon the water, vnlesse they would incurre the losse of their shippes, for our men being on lande could not let them to effray those that were left in the shippes, being but a small number in comparison to the enimies, the which seemed vnto vs an intollerable losse, specially that we coulde sende no cōmoditie into France for to let the kings Maiestie vnderstande the estate of our enterprise. Therefore vpon Monday the tenth day of September, thrée houres before noone, the Capitaine and kings Lieutenant would sée all his men, and after that he had exhorted them to do well in the Kings seruice, toke shipping with them, taking for his defence not onely the Souldiers that he had newelye brought thither, but also the best of them that kept ye place before, also the chiefe standard of Capitain Lauduniere. This Capitaine being weryed without hearing newes out of Frauce,
and displeased for that he was depriued of foode, a little before ye we aryued thither, thought to returne againe into France, and in the meane time did not care much if his company did that to the Countrey Inhabitants, wherby their good affection might be turned from the Frenche men, but he suffered them to force them and bring them prisoners to their Holde, to take by force their Mill, and other things that necessitie, whiche can bée vnder no law, did constraine them. And for so much as desire of vengeance is naturally planted in mannes heart, also that the common appetite of all beastes is to defende their bodyes and lyues, and to auoyde those thinges that shall séeme hurtefull, it is not therefore to be doubted, but that these wilde men did confederate with the Spaniards, how they might be deliuered of vs French men, with whom they were both in body and goodes trauayled & payned. The Tuesday being the .xj. of September, aboute eight of the clocke in the morning or there about, when that oure Capitaine was very nere to the Spaniards
there did rise a great wind which cōtinued a long tyme, with great showers of raine, thunders & lightnings, in such sorte that the ayre was some tymes like fyre, so that both partes being afrayed of the rage of ye weather, seperated our thrée shippes, being faine to abide the weather, and the Spanish shippes made the winde good: and the rage of the weather dured till the .xxiij. day of September. Now the Spaniards being descended on land, had leysure enough to espie & séeke out a way vnto the Holde, and to inuent the meanes howe to entrappe vs, knowing that our General was at sea with ye chiefe strēgth, looking for fayre weather, and that those that remayned in oure Holde were the most part sicke, being altered by the smel of the Sea, part handycraftes men with women and children, being in all to the number of two hundreth & forty soules, vnder the garde and diligenee of Capitaine Lauduniere, which misdoubted nothing lesse, than that a companie might come by lande to entrappe them. Wherefore our Capitaine did rise earely in the
morning for to refreshe him, bycause of the foule weather that had bene ye nighte before, opening the wicket an houre before the Sunne rysing, the most parte of vs in the Holde being fast a sléepe and in our beddes. The Spaniardes hauing trauersed Woods, Dytches and Ryuers, being conducted by the wylde and barbarous men, aryued the Monday being the xx. day of September, in the morning earely to our Holde, the morning being very cloudy and rayny, and entered therin without any resistance, whereas they made a most horrible and dolefull slaughter of our men, such a rage and crueltie they had conceyued against our Nation. They sought then who could best cut the throtes of men, hole & sicke, women & litle children, a pitisull sight and lamentable. Some of our men, ye most nimblest, stepping out of their beddes, got away and saned them selues in the shippes that were in the ryuer, being left there by our Generall, vnder the keping of Iames Ribaut Capitaine of a shippe named the Pearle, and vnder Luis Ballard his Lieutenant:
the others being almost intrapped, leaped ouer the fence or wall of our Holde, the Capitaine Lauduniere saued him selfe by that meanes, with hir that serued him in his Chamber. I was almost taken sodenlye going to my worke, my toole in my hande, for comming out of my Cabane, I met the enimies, so that I knewe no other meanes to escape, but to turne my backe and hye me as fast as was possible to leape ouer the fence or wall, for I was coursed with a Pike man, and I knowe not how otherwise but only by the grace of God, my strength doubled poore olde man that I am & gray headed, notwythstāding I leaped ouer the Ramper, which in taking aduisement I coulde not haue done, for it was eight or nine foote highe, so that when I was ouer, I hasted to saue me in the Woods, and about the distance of a bowe shoote, when that I was néere to the Wood, I turned my face towarde the Holde & stayed a little, and that more holder for that no man followed me. And as from the place where I stode, I might easely sée the Holde, so did I heare an horrible
cry of the slaughter that was made af our men, and thrée auncients of oure aduersaries planted vpon the Rampers. Hauing now lost all hope to sée our men together, I put my selfe into the mercye of God, and launched into the thickest of the wood, for this I thought, that I should not finde more greater crueltie among the wylde beastes, than the crueltie that the enimies extended vpon our men. The miserie and trouble wherewith I felt my self wrapped, seing in earth no more hope but that the lord God of his speciall grace aboue mannes hope might deliuer me, it made me therfore cast sighes and teares, and with a voyce full of sorrow I began to cal vnto God after this fore, saying: O God of our fathers and Lorde of all consolation, which hath commaunded vs to call vpon thée euē from the laake of Hell and panges of death, promising thy sodaine ayde and helpe, shewe vnto me, for the hope that I haue in thée, what way I might take for to come to the ende of this miserable age, plonged in the gulfe of sorrow and bitternesse, at the least cause
me that féeling the effect of thy mercy, the assurance that I haue conceyued in my heart of thy promises, be not taken away by the cruelty & furious rage of the wilde beasts on the one side, and of thy enimies and ours on the other side, the which séeke our death more for that thy holy name is called vpon amongst vs, than for any other thing. Helpe me O god, assist me, for I am so aflicted that I can call no more.

And in the meane time whilest I made this discourse, trauesing the Wood very thicke of Brears and Thornes, vnder the hyghe trées where as there was neyther pathe nor way, wherein I had bene not aboue the space of halfe an houre, but that I hearde a noyse, as though it were the wepings and complaintes of men that were aboute me: notwithstanding, I going forwarde in the name of God, hauing confidence in his helpe, I discouered one of oure companie named Lasieur of Blonderie, and another behinde him, named mayster Robert, being well knowen of vs all, for that he had the charge to say seruice in oure Holde, shortely after
came to vs the Lackeys of Le Sieur de Vlly, the Nephewe of Mounseur Beau, Master Iames Teuse, and many others. So being gathered together, we did consult of our miseries, deliberating of that which we had to do for the sauing of our liues. And amōgst vs one being somwhat séene in the Scriptures, began after this maner, saying: Brethren, ye sée in what extremitie we are, what parte soeuer we turne our eyes, we se nothing but barbarousnesse, the heauen, the earth, the sea, the woods, the men, & to be short, nothing fauoureth vs. What knowe we if that in yelding vs to the fauor of the Spaniards, they wil shew fauour. Wel, yet although they kill vs, it shall be suffered but for a time, they are men, and it may be that their fury being appeased, they will receyue vs on composition, otherwise what should we do, is it not better for vs to fall into the handes of man, than into the mouthes of wilde beastes, or rather to die for hunger in a straunge lande. After that he had fayde these wordes, the most parte of oure companye was of his aduise, and
praysed his counsell. Notwithstanding that I shewed them the crueltye, yet all bloudy, of oure aduersaries, and that it was not only for one cause and humaine debate that they had executed with such a fury their enterprise, but principally for the knowledge that hath bene giuē them, that we are of those that are returned to the preaching of the Gospell: let vs not the refore be so wilfull as to trust in man more than in God, which maketh those that are his to liue, yea, euen in the midst of the dead, and giueth alwayes his helpe when that the hope of man fayleth. Also I did alleage certaine examples oute of the holy Scripture for the purpose, of Ioseph, Daniel, Elias, and other Prophets. Also of the Apostles, as of S. Peter, and of S. Paule, the which all, being brought out of affliction, yea, by extraordinarye meanes, and straunge to the sense and reason of man, his arme I say is not at al weakened, his hande is alwayes one. Remember ye not (saide I) howthe children of Israell fledde from Pharao, what hope had this people to escape the handes of
Tyrant mighty and cruell, he followed them euē hard at their héeles, before them they had the red sea, on both sides mighty hye hilles, what then, he that opened the sea for to make a way for his people, and afterwarde swallowed vppe the enimies therin, might not he in like maner guide vs through the woods and fieldes of this straunge Countrey. For all that I could say, sixe of the company followed the first preposition, and left vs, taking their way to their enimies, hoping to finde fauour and grace before them, but they knew incontinently and by experience, what folly it is to trust more in mē than to ye promises of our god. For being once come forth of the wood, as they thought to haue gone to the Fort, beholde they were taken by a cōpany of Spaniards, and intreated like vnto the others, they were killed, & then drawen to the Ryuer side, whereas the others being slain in the Holde lay on heapes. And I will tell an exāple of extreme cruelty. Iames Rybaut capitaine of the Pearle, rid with his shippe at an Anker about a hundreth paces from the Holde,
and receyued many of those that escaped this slaughter. The Spaniards hauing their hearts great, bicause of their victory, were bent to dispatch the rest of ye Frēch men, made ready the ordinance against the shippes and boates, but bicause of the raynie weather, and for that the Gunnes were oute of order, they did no harme to our men, but they sent a Trumpet vnto them to summō them to yelde, but when they sawe that this feared them nothing, they sente one of their men euen vnto the Shippes, shewing the authoritie of Dom Pedre Maluendo, generall of their company, for to compound with our men on this condition, that they shoulde leaue the shippes and goe their wayes in their Boates with their baggage to the other shippes that were more lower at ye mouth of the Ryuer, distant from the Holde about two Leagues, to ye which our men aunswered, that there was no warre betwene them, when that aboute sixe Monthes passed, they had receyued commaundement of the King to make this voyage, so that we haue not enterprised to do any
wrong or exaction to any man, for it was expressiuely defended by his Maiestie, & also of his Admyral, yt we should make no discent in any part of Spaine, nor yet to come neare, for feare of offending them. We haue kepte and obserued the kinges commaundemēt inuiolately, so that you can not saye against vs, that we are the cause of this slaughter yt you haue made of our men, against all vsage of warre, the whiche maketh our hearts to bléede, for the which dede you may hereafter being in tyme and place, féele. And as touching the shippe that you demaunde, you shall sooner haue our lyues, and whereas you thinke to constraine vs, we will employ the meane that God & nature hath giuen vs to defende vs. The Spaniarde being returned backe, did report that our men feared them nothing, but that they were minded to stande to defence. Then this furious company cast the coller and bloudy dispight vpon the deade bodyes, and shewed them to the French mē that rested vpō the water, so that they sought to hurt the soules of them of whome they
woulde if that they coulde dismember the body, for pulling out the dead mens eies, they did sticke them on their Dagger poyntes, and then with exclamations, cauntes, and mockings, threwe them towarde the Frenche men that were vpon the water. As for vs that remained in the woods, we continued trauesing, keping to out iudgement the right course to the Sea. And as it pleased God to direct our steppes and adresse our wayes, by and by we came to the croupe of a hill, and from thence we perceyued the Sea, but for all that there was great distance, and that worsse was, the way that we had to take séemed maruellous straunge and harde. Firste the Mountayne whiche it behoued vs to discende downe, was of such a heygth and so slope, that it was not possible for any man keping him on his legges to descend, so that none of vs durst descende but for the hope that we had of certaine shrubbes and Brears that grew on this hilles side, by the helpe of which we gat downe, not without great paine, in scratching and renting our hands and
our legges, yea our bodyes also being all bloudy. Being descended from the hil, we lost sight of the Sea by reason of a little wood that was planted before vs, and for to goe to the wood, it behoued vs to trauesse a great field being marish ground, wherin did grow many wilde Roses and other straunge hearbes, of which the stalkes being harde as wood, and the leaues, cutte our féete and our legges euen to the bloude, being alwayes in water vp to the knées, and that that doubled our miserie and calamitie, was, that the raine did fall from heauen in such sort, that we were as betwene two waters, and the farther we went, the deper we found ye water. Then thinking that we were come to the laste end of our life, we embraced one another, and with a common affection we began to sighe and crye vnto the Lorde God, accusing our sinnes, and knowing vpon vs the rygor of his iudgements. Alas O lord God (sayde we) what are we any other than pore wormes of the earth, our soules being altered and chaunged with sorrow and griefe, doth yelde them into thy handes
O Father full of mercy, and God of Charitie, deliuer vs out of this place of death, or if thou wilte that in this deserte we make an ende of our liues, assist vs O Lorde, that death which of all things is most terriblest, when he commeth to take holde of vs, that he feare vs not, but that we may remayne firine & stable in minde of thy fauour and good will that we haue so many tymes tasted on and approued in thy Sonne Iesus Christ, for to giue place to the spirite of Sathan, the spirite of dispaire and defiaunce. For be it that we dye, we protest nowe before thy Malestie, that we wil die to thée, be it that we liue, it shall be to tell of thy maruellous workes, in the middest of the congregatiō of thy Saintes. Our prayers ended, we went forwarde with great payne to the wood, in so much that we arriued nere to a great Ryuer that ranne throughe the midst of this fielde, the breadth was not very great, but very depe, and the water ranne with great swiftnesse, for so much as this fielde was not farre from the sea. This Ryner was an other increasing of
our sorowes, for there was not one of our men that durst swim ouer the Riuer. Being in this confusion of thoughts how to passe ouer, Iremembred the wood that we left behinde vs. After that I had erhorted my brethren to patience, & to continue in good hope of Gods mercy, I returned to the wood and cut a long piece of wood with an ende of a Bill that was left in my hande at the houre that the Holde was taken, I came againe to the others that taryed me in great perplexitie. Now brethren, sayde I, let vs see if that God by this staffe will shewe vs fauour to bring our iourney to an ende, so we layde the staffe or forke vpon the water, one of our men, and also euery one following his turne, holding it by the end, and entring into the water caried the forke with him, and in the midst of the water, as we lost the sight of it, we pushed it with force and strength to the other side wheras we toke lande, with the helpe of the Réedes and other hearbes that grew on the brinke, and so we passed all one after another, but it was not without great daunger, & drinking
much salte water, yea, such a quan titie, that comming to the other side, oure heartes fayled vs, & we were as one that is halfe drowned. After that we were come to our sclues, & had taken courage, tending alwayes to the wood, the which we had marked to be nere to the Sea, the forke also was necessary to passe an other arme of water, whiche gaue vs no lesse paine to passe than the first, but thankes be to God we passed it, and towarde the night, we entered into the Wood, where we remayned all the night in great sorrowe and feare, standing vpright oure backes to the trées, and for all our greate trauayle & iourneys, yet we had no mind to sléepe, for what rest could the spirites haue being in such fears? Also we saw about the poynt of day a beast, greate, lyke vnto a stagge, within fiftye pases of vs, whose heade was very bigge, the eies flaming, the eares hanging, hauing ye hinder partes indifferent. She séemed vnto vs verye monstrous bycause of hir eyes, whiche séemed as thoughe they were flaming, being very great, the which came
not neare vs, for to doe vs anye harme. The day being come, we came out of the woode and then we sawe the Sea for the whiche we had wished so much, nexte to god, as an only meane to saue our liues: but we were againe troubled, for we saw it all a marish ground full of water and couered with briars & wilde Roses like to ye which we trauessed the day before. We went forward trauessing these marishes, and neare vnto the place where as wée were mynded for to goe, we perceyued amongst the wylde Rosiers a companie of men, which at the first sighte we thought had béene our enimies which were come thither to curte our waye, but when that we had behelde more neare, we saw that they were desolate & naked as we were, by the which we knew that they were of our men, for there was the captaine Lauduniere, his chamber mayd, Iames Morgens of Déepe, and Fraunces Duuall of Roane, with many others to the number of .xxvi. persons, vpon the deliberation of that which we hadde to doe. One of oure men clymed vpō one of the highest trées,
where hée discouered one of oure little shippes whiche was vnder the charge of captaine Mailarde, to whome they gaue a signe, by the which they vnderstoode our néede: so he caused his little barke to come neare, but to approch the sea banke it behoued vs to passe through these wilde roses, and two little ryuers like vnto those that we had passed the daye before, to the which was very necessarie our pearch or Forke that I had cut the day before, and other two that Captaine Lauduniere had made prouision of, so that we came nere ynough to the Bark, but our hearts sayled vs, what for hunger and trauaile. So that we had remayned there, had not the Mariners holpen vs, which shewed them selues verye succourable: and they bare vs one after another into their Barke, and so caryed vs to their shippe, whereas we were well and chéerefullye receyued. They gaue vs breade and water, and after that we had eaten, we began by little and little to receyue strength, which was a most sure token of Gods mercy, who had saued vs, againste the hope of infinite
daungers of death, with the whiche we were compassed on all sides, for to rēder vnto him meste heartie thankes and prayse for euer. So we passed the nighte talking of the miraculous workes of god, and comforting one another in remembrance of our deliuerie. The day being come, Iames Rybaut Capitaine of the Pearle, bourded vs, for to conferre with vs what were best to be done, for to saue the rest of our men and shippes, and then it was shewed the scarcitie of vittayles that we had, our strengthes broken, oure munitions of warre in our enimies handes, the vncertain estate of our gouernor, not knowing whither the rage of the tēpest had driuen them. We concluded therfore that we coulde doe no better than to assay to returne into France, and ye chiefest of our company were of this aduise, to seperate in two partes those that were escaped from the Holde, and that some of them should be in the Pearle, and the rest vnder the charge of Capitaine Mailarde. So on Thursday being the .xxv. of September, we parted from the coast, by the
fauour of a Northerly winde, minding to sayle into Fraunce. And since the first day oure shippes were so parted, that we met no more vpon the seas together. We sayled .v. hundreth Leagues happely, but in a morning before the Sunne rising, we were assayled of a Spanishe shippe whom we susteyned to our powers, & we so beate him with Gunne shotce, that we made him yelde to our willes, & we beate him in such sort, that the bloud ranne out at the skupper holes, so that no man was sene aboue hatches: but we could not bord them bycause of the weather, for feare of brousing our ship. They also being content, let vs goe, & so we left them, thanks be to God, and ioyfull of that which had happened, and for that none of vs was hurte nor killed in this fight, sauing oure Cooke. The rest of our nauigation hath bene without meting of our enimies, but we haue bene sore weather beaten, and almost driuen on ye Spanish coast, which had bene an increasing of our sorrows, & the thing that we did most abhorre. We haue also endured on ye Seas many other
things, as colde, and hunger. For you shall vnderstande, that we that were escaped from Terra Florida, had no other apparell left, neyther for the nighte, nor yet for the day, but one poore shirt, and another little thin thing vpon it, which was very little to defende vs from the iniurie of the weather, and that worsse was, the breade that we did cate, was fenoed and naught. Also the fresh water that we had, did stinke, of the which we had all the day long, but one taster or smal cup ful. This naughty and corrupt nourishment is the cause, that we being descended a shore, are fallen into so many kinds of diseases and sicknesses, the which hath caused to dye a great many of our company. And at the end of this perillous and lamentable nauigation, we were dryuen on the coast of Rochell, whereas we haue bene gently intreated of the inhabitants of the Coūtrey, and of those of the towne, giuing vs of their goods so much as necessitie required, being assisted of their good willes, we had sufficient for euery one to returne into his Countrey.

div.head: The seconde booke.
div.p:
YE haue hearde howe Capitaine Iohn Rybaut tooke shipping with ye souldiers for to finde out the Spaniards, and so hauing sought them the space of fiue dayes, and not finding them, he met the Admirall of his fléete, named the Trinitie, and being minded to kepe the coast against the Spaniardes, not knowing of that which had happened at the Holde, entered therein, according to the ordinarie custome. The weather was troublesome, for that the winde blewe so extremely, and it rayned continually. The fift day the tempest encreased after suche sorte, that they were not able to resist it, but of force were dryuen to the shore aboue the Ryuer of May about fiftie Leagues, and there the ships were broken, and their munitions lost, notwithstanding the men came on lande, sauing the Capitaine Grange, which caste him selfe
vpon a mast and was drowned, a man among the others much to be lamented, as well for the good counsell that he alwayes gaue, as also for the fruites of his amiable acquaintance. Our men being then saued on shore from the rage of the waues, found them selues wrapped in another trouble, for to ye hunger that helde them, there was no remedy, vnlesse they woulde eate suche thinges as the earth brought forth, that is to wit, hearbes, rootes, and suche like, with the which they thought to satisfie their crauing stomack. There was not neyther to satisfie their thirst, but olde Cesternes wherin the water was much troubled, for the skum that it did cast, to loke to was enough to make a whole body sicke, notwithstanding, the rage of their extreme hunger and thirste caused them to digest these vnholesome meates and drinks, which semed to them very strange, and they were in this perplexitie the tearme of eyght dayes. The ninth day by fortune they founde a little Barke, for the which they were somwhat comforted, hoping by that meanes to let
them of the Holde vnderstande of their shipwracke. Now betwéene them and the Holde it was .xij. Leagues by lande, and fiftie by water, and betwéene them and the Forte was the Ryuer of Dolphins, which is very depe, and of the breadth of one quarter of a Mile, wherfore without some vessel, it was vnpossible for them to passe ouer. When then they had receyued this Barke, they did caulke it with their shirts in stede of Okum. Then ye capitaine Iohn Ribaut of his grace and accustomed modestie, called many to his counsel and said vnto them after this fort: Companions and friendes, it is not for vs to continewe our lyues in such miserie and calamitie, it were better for vs to wishe for death, than to liue being charged with suche afflictions, vnlesse that God of his grace hath giuen vs fayth of his prouidence for to looke for succour, suche as it shall please him to sende vs, and in the meane time, let vs employ oure minds to séeke out the issue of these troubles. I am of this mind, that there be some amongst vs, the which shall go to the Fort in this
litle Barke, for to let our men vnderstād oure extreme néede, to the ende that they giue vs succoure, and being on the shore casting out many teares, they began to call vpon the name of God knéeling on their knées. When their prayers were finished, they beganne to looke, which of them were most aptest to sende: and they named Thomas Le Vasseur of Déepe, to whome Captaine Iohn Ribaut gaue the charge, that assone as he could, he should let them of the Forte vnderstande their distresse, and with him there went Vyncent Symon, Michell Gouer, and others to the number of sixtene. Our men, as I sayd before, were on the contrary side of the holde, for the riuer of Dolphins was betwene thē and the holde, so that going forwarde on lande toward the Fort, they sawe the very same day, on the other side of the riuer, a cōpany of men of Armes with their Standerds spread, & after that they had known by coniectures that they were Spanyards, our Frenchmen were perplexed in their heartes, knowing not what to doe, but for their best remedye,
they sent some of their cōpanie swiming ouer the riuer for to make offer to yelde, their liues saued. The swimmers were receyued at the first very curtcously, the Captaine of this Spanish company was named Vallemande, who sware by the fayth of a gentleman & christian knight, to vse his good will towarde the Frenchmen, also that it was the order alwayes practised in warre, that the Spaniard being victorious, should be contēt, specially with Frenchmen, without attempting further, and he shewed vs also by signes, to the ende that we might be persuaded of this fayre promisse, yt herein we should finde no fault, that the nations hereafter shoulde not speake thereof. And incontinētly he caused a Barge to be made readye, into the which he commaunded fiue Spaniardes to enter to passe ouer oure mē, the which they did. Now this Barge being come to the other side, and that the Spaniardes had made a narration in the name of Vallemande, the Captaine Iohn Ribaut entered first into the Barge, and others to the number of thirtie, and he
was gently receyued of Vallemande, but the others that were of his companie were caried further off & all bound, their hands behind there backes, two and two together, so the rest of our men passed ouer by thirtye at a tyme, whylest that Vallemande entertayned our good Captaine Iohn Ribaut with fayre flattering wordes, the which trusted to the faythfull promisse of the sayde Vallemande, to whome he had yelded. Now our men as they came ouer, were bound two to two, and being altogether Frenchmen and Spaniardes, they went toward the Fort, the Captaine Iohn Ribaut and others, specially the Sieur of Ottigny when they sawe our men coupled together, began to chaunge countenaunce, and agayne desired the sayde Vallemandes fauoure, who assured them, saying that those bāds were only to bring them to the holde in saftie, and that there he woulde kepe that which he had promised. And when they were neare to the holde, he enquired of them whiche were Mariners, Carpenters of shippes, goonners and others which were
necessarie to the offices of the Sea, the which being chosē out, were thirty men. And shortly after, beholde a cōpany came from the Holde to oure men, who were made to come behinde the Sieur of Vallamande & his companie, like a companie of beastes that are dryuen to the slaughter. Then with the noise of Drums, Flutes and Trumpets, the courage of these furious Spaniardes was extended vpon the poore Frenchmen which were bound. There was assay who coulde best strike with the Pike, Haulberd and sworde, in such sort, that within halfe an houre they wonne the fielde and name of this glorious victorie, killing those there, most cruelly, which were yelded, and whome they had receyued on their fayth and alleageance. During this crueltie the Capitaine Iohn Rybaut made certaine exhortations to Vallamande to saue his lyfe. Also the Sieur of Ottigny knéeling on his knées, remembring Vallamande of his faythfull promisse, but all was to no effect, for he turning his backe, went a little from them, & then one of his murtherers stroke
the Capitane Iohn Rybaut behinde with a Dagger, that he made him fall downe, and then doubled his strokes, till that he had taken his life from him. After suche sorte were our men handled, that before vnder the shadowe of assurance made by the Spaniards, had yelded. And for to shewe the more crueltie, they rente the Kings Lieutenants beard in despite, and for a shewe of there expedition, the which shortly after they sente to Syuell, as certaine of our Mariners, reserued for thys voyage, haue few dayes passed faithfully shewed vs, specially one Chrystopher le Britton of New Hauen, the which secretly departed from Syuell to the towne of Burdeux, and from thence by ship came to Déepe, and for a memorial of their victorie, they quartred the body of this faithfull seruant of the King, Iohn Rybaut, and of his head made foure quarters, the which they did sticke at the foure endes of the Fort.

Here haste thou (gentle Reader) séene the discourse of two sorts of people, wherin thou mayest iudge with indifferencie,
and sée what couetousnesse causeth, being both desirous of gaine, and in specially the monstruous crueltie of the one part. But the Historie suffiseth of it selfe, God is a righteous iudge which séeth the actes of all humaine kinde, and shall rewarde euery one according to their deserts. God kéepe vs from murther and bloudshedde, and giue vs grace to feare him, and honour his holy name aright. Amen.
